title: Extended unpacking (*rest): splitting sequences, safe patterns, and common errors
content:
Extended iterable unpacking lets you capture “the remaining items” in a sequence using a starred target. This is extremely useful when parsing structured data like lines, tokens, or tuples.

---
## 1) First/rest pattern

```python
first, *rest = [10, 20, 30, 40]
print(first)  # 10
print(rest)   # [20, 30, 40]
```

---
## 2) Head/middle/tail pattern

```python
head, *middle, tail = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
print(head)    # 1
print(middle)  # [2, 3, 4]
print(tail)    # 5
```

---
## 3) Practical parsing example (tokenizing)

```python
cmd = "git commit -m 'hello'".split()
program, subcmd, *args = cmd

print(program)  # git
print(subcmd)   # commit
print(args)     # ['-m', "'hello'"]
```

---
## 4) Nested unpacking (moderate complexity)

```python
record = ("user1", (10, 20), ["admin", "active"])
name, (x, y), flags = record
print(name, x, y, flags)
```

---
## 5) Common errors to recognize
### Too many values to unpack

```python
# a, b = (1, 2, 3)  # ValueError: too many values to unpack
```

### Not enough values to unpack

```python
# a, b, c = (1, 2)  # ValueError: not enough values to unpack
```

### Only one starred target is allowed

```python
# a, *b, *c = range(5)  # invalid
```

---
## 6) A chunk-friendly “many shapes” practice section

```python
values = [1, 2, 3, 4]
a, *b, c = values
print(a, b, c)  # 1 [2, 3] 4
```

```python
pair = ("x", 1)
key, val = pair
print(key, val)
```

```python
letters = "ABCDE"
*prefix, last = letters
print(prefix, last)  # ['A','B','C','D'] E
```
